title: How to Drill Holes on an Engine Lathe Using the Carriage

steps.headline: Attach the chuck to the lathe according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Loosen off the chuck, mount your work into the chuck and then re-tighten the chuck.
Select your tooling and speeds and feeds.
Mount a lathe center in the tailstock.
Place the drill with the square split bushing into the tool post and shim or adjust to ensure that the drill center lines up with the lathe center.
steps.description: Once centered, tighten the clamping screws to secure the drill.

steps.headline: Square the drill bit to the side of the work piece using paper feelers and tighten the tool post bolt or compound rest nuts.
Set up a center drill in the tool post, centering it with the lathe center in the tailstock.
steps.description: Ensure that you do not loosen the tool post bolt or compound rest nuts since the tool post is already squared to the work piece. Also make sure that the center of the center drill is the same distance as the center of the drill bit from the back of the tool post.

steps.headline: Remove work piece from chuck and insert a drill or straight shank center
Move carriage so that the center drill is close to the chucked drill or center.
steps.description: Use cross slide to align the center of the center drill with the center of the chucked drill or center and lock cross slide if possible.

steps.headline: Remove bit/center from chuck and replace the work piece.
Select center drill and turn on lathe
Move carriage close to the work piece.
Apply coolant and start peck drilling with the carriage hand wheel (no power feed).
Move carriage away from the work piece and select the drill.
Move drill close to the work piece and engage the power feed.
Once you have reached the desired depth, disengage the power feed and remove the drill.
Turn lathe off and remove the work piece.
